Q4: Productive, respectful relationships between a boss and his or her employees is key to any company’s success. While the boss’ top priority is likely to have hardworking employees who fulfill his vision for the company, it’s a safe bet that he’d also like to have more than superficial relationships with the people he works with every day. After all, he probably spends more time with his staff than he does with anyone else. There have been a number of times that I’ve shared ideas with employees, and they’ve come back and suggested—politely of course—that my idea may not be the best route. The reason I don’t get upset is because, along with the rejection of my idea, they present a suggestion for something else. Or, better still, they consider how they can adapt my idea and make it work more effectively.
Q5: When I first started my business, it was easy to meet with each employee almost daily, because I only had five employees. Now, with 19, it is more difficult to check in with every employee every day and keep tabs on all the tasks that each person is working on. So it’s important that my employees take the initiative to set up individual meetings with me throughout the month. This helps me know what’s going on in the business—and shows me that they care about their jobs and are keeping my goals and expectations in mind. I would always rather have employees tell me when something at work or at home is affecting the rest of their lives than to wonder why their productivity has suddenly dipped or why they’ve developed a bad attitude. So, if you’re a parent whose office hours are taking a toll on your family, propose a schedule that allows you to work from home part-time. Or, if you’re a part-time college student who needs some extra time off during finals week, see if there is a way to make up the time elsewhere in your schedule. Ask for what you need and be willing to compromise, and your relationship with your manager will be better for it.

Some advice from my leader
A team leader should be a role model to his team members. He should treat each and every individual as one and avoid partiality at work Do not give anyone a special treatment just because he drops your son to school every day or says a yes to whatever you say. Appreciate if someone has done exceptionally well but do make sure to correct him if he is wrong somewhere. The team leader should not be rude or harsh to anyone. There is a correct way for everything and one should not insult any team member. It is strictly unethical. Sit with him and make him realize his mistakes. He would definitely look up to you in future.

The superior must not act pricy and should always be accessible to his employees. The individuals must have the liberty to walk up to their immediate bosses in case of a doubt and clear things. The hierarchy should not be too complicated as it leads to confusions and disputes among employees.

The manager must ensure that all important communication takes place on an open forum for everyone to get a common picture. Problems arise when communication is done on a one to one basis. Call everyone together so that all the members are clear as to what is expected out of them and what their colleagues are up to. Communication should be transparent for an effective employee relation. Any employee should not feel neglected or left out. If the team leader wants to pass on any information to his team members, he must send a mail keeping all the related members in the loop.

As a team leader it is one’s prime responsibility to encourage healthy competition at work. Competition is mandatory for an individual’s growth but it should not turn friends to foes. Motivate them constantly to perform better than the other but make sure there are no useless gossips in your team. If you find any of your team members criticizing or making fun of anyone, stop him immediately. Do not provoke any individual to fight, instead intervene and try to resolve the conflict as soon as possible.

Make sure all your team members take their lunch together and you are also a part of it. Don’t discuss work that time. Let them enjoy. Encourage everyone to talk to each other and participate in discussions. Do take the initiative to ask about their families or personal lives as well. They would feel attached to you. If you find any two of your team members not getting along well with each other, make sure both of them work together on the same assignment. They would not be left with any choice than to talk to each other and discuss things. Make them sit together on adjacent workstations so that the comfort level increases. 

The team leader should be neutral to his team members and make sure they enjoy a healthy relationship with him as well as their fellow team members for a better output. A team leader should try his level best to bring his team members closer and bind them together.

Also describe some problems with solution with their experience 

Increase positive emotional connections with others. Just like the flu or a cold, emotions are contagious. If a leader is angry or frustrated that emotion spreads to others.  On the other hand, if a leader is positive and optimistic those emotions also spread. Be aware of your emotional state and work to spread the positive emotions.
Display rock solid integrity. Do others trust you to keep your commitments and promise.Are others confident that you will be fair and do the right thing? We like those we trust, we dislike those we distrust.

Considerations
While many companies employ workers without formal agreements, others have employment-at-will contracts with the workers. The company can terminate the employee for almost any reason, as long as the firm does not make its firing decision based on discrimination or whistle-blowing. This arrangement is sometimes a source of conflict between employee and manager, because the employee is afraid of losing his job.

Recessionary times can negatively affect the relationship between employee and employer. An employee may start to distrust the company more and fear losing his job because of hard financial times. Downturns in the economy actually might be an opportunity for managers to build employee loyalty to the company. Authors Stephen A. Miles and Nathan Bennett, in a "Bloomberg Business Week" article, state that "employers find themselves more frequently asking employees to trust the company—assuring employees that better days are ahead and their efforts today will not be forgotten tomorrow."

If an employer disregards the concerns of employees, that could lead to a number of important and sometimes expensive problems. Besides turnover, workplace violence is also a risk to the business if employees become disgruntled. Employees who feel slighted by managers may also compromise the security of the company's proprietary information by either sharing trade secrets or taking that valuable knowledge to another competing business. A company that doesn't foster a productive relationship between employees and managers also may develop a poor reputation in the industry.

Employers can take steps toward improving the employee and manager relationship to facilitate a highly productive and happy workplace. For one, managers can implement employee recognition or reward programs to thank workers for a job well done. Meetings and regular communications between employees and managers are also important, especially if workers feel disconnected from the management of the company.

Many times confusions among the team members arise when communication is done on a one to one basis between the manager and subordinates. If a manager wants to build an effective employee relationship, he/she should try to communicate in a transparent manner regarding what is expected out of them and what their colleagues are up to. It’s very crucial to hold open communication forum at least a month having all the team members on board.

Even more importantly, the manager should give feedbacks to the subordinates. It can be positive feedback; even it can be a negative feedback. But, without communicating the mistakes of the subordinates, the manager should not expect improvement in the work of the subordinate. Open communication about mistake and positive feedbacks will make the life of a manager easier without losing his/her ground

Q4:
A particular danger in these situations is that people or organizations that are being managed by such an individual or group think they're being led; but they're not. There may actually be no leadership at all, with no one setting a vision and no one being inspired. This can cause serious problems in the long term.

In the transformational leadership model, leaders set direction and help themselves and others to do the right thing to move forward. To do this they create an inspiring vision, and then motivate and inspire others to reach that vision. They also manage delivery of the vision, either directly or indirectly, and build and coach their teams to make them ever stronger.
Q5:
In the transformational leadership model, leaders set direction and help themselves and others to do the right thing to move forward. To do this they create an inspiring vision, and then motivate and inspire others to reach that vision. They also manage delivery of the vision, either directly or indirectly, and build and coach their teams to make them ever stronger.
A particular danger in these situations is that people or organizations that are being managed by such an individual or group think they're being led; but they're not. There may actually be no leadership at all, with no one setting a vision and no one being inspired. This can cause serious problems in the long term.

Q4: When I first came on board, my manager went through all the steps of what would be my duties for my job.  She went above and beyond to give me tips on how things work at the organization.  She is always willing to listen and to help her employees when we need it.  If I have issues that need to be addressed, she takes the time to go over what is wrong.  There have been times when I needed some time off for personal reasons, and she was more than willing to accommodate my needs.  She also does not allow her workers to engage in drama.  My coworkers and I all have similar experiences with her, as she's consistent across the board with all of us.
Q5: My manager is always available to her workers when we need her to be.  Any time there are issues in the department, she goes out of her way to make sure everything is completed the way it's expected to be completed.  If there are any issues with either the work or other coworkers, she will sit down with us privately and jointly to make sure things aren't getting out of hand.  She refuses to allow any kind of drama in the company, which is almost unheard of in my type of business.  She will periodically go over what's expected of us, and if any areas are lacking or there are misunderstandings she will go over each in detail, just to be sure we have a clear picture of our duties.  One example is when there was something we had available for sale, and there was an issue with the amount of stock we had on hand.  We were unsure of exactly what we had, so my manager decided to take it upon herself and actually go to physically see what was available.  That took a lot of time out of her personal time off.

Q4: My working relationship with leader is cordial, clear, polite, but casual. There is a certain sense of comraderie "in the trenches," so to speak, in dealing with the chaos all around and all the little fires that have to be put out. She does provide advice, and some short- to mid-range goals for me and is supportive of that, but I usually have to find my own formal training programs or development -- through conferences, webinars through a professional organization, or through online MOOCs such as edX or Coursera. She shows respect mainly by letting me take my own initiative to set forth certain things that I want to achieve -- like projects of my own making that help her, help our department, and help the entire organization at large -- without asking for me to do them. She doesn't mind me coming in to her office to talk, and is happy to just talk sometimes about all sorts of things. I believe the relationship I have with her is on par with others in immediate unit save for a few, with one person having a worse relationship with her, and another person having a better relationship. Me and my manager started on the exact same day, and a few other colleagues came in thereafter. The person she doesn't have a great relationship with has been here the longest, before her. The one who has a much better relationship with my manager has somehow ingratiated herself to an extent where she's received promotions ahead of what my other colleagues -- even the one who's been here longer than any of us -- have received.
Q5: She provides support mainly through listening to what we want to accomplish within the parameters of our job functions -- and actually going a bit above and beyond -- as well as just staying out of our way, and providing feedback. However, as far as material support goes, I've tried asking for certain computer programs or online services that are used by professionals (but cost $7,500-$10,000) for the department but she usually just says "that's a bit pricey, I'll have to check higher up." She never gives me a yes/no, so I have to presume the answer is "no" so that I can give a fair answer to salespersons who are trying to work with me, so that those salespersons aren't left dangling. She listens to concerns and provides advice readily, but sometimes it's like she truly never really has a good response to them. This perhaps not a standard work concern that you have received from other respondents, but I used to be a journalist, and I received a threat from a man I wrote about almost 10 years ago. This happened this past summer around the time of the Orlando Pulse massacre, and also being LGBT, I was extremely on edge. She was highly dismissive at first, and was publicly so. It took me being very very assertive and me writing things down formally in emails, including one to the organization's ombudsperson as well as a few to individuals in my organization trained in trauma response, mass shootings and hate crimes, for her to take things seriously, and her also to realize that as a gay man, I was under severe stress, on edge, and in a sense of hyperawareness at the time. She apologized later, and after work over drinks she really really apologized and said she did not realize how I must have felt. It's sad it took 49 people dying and emails to people in other parts of the organization for her to stop being dismissive, but it's what it is. As far as coaching and mentoring, it's casual sit-down type stuff when I have questions, just office chats, about advice about what to do in certain situations.

Q4:

Q4: My manager offers her assistance in the form of an "open door" policy.  She encourages any employee who feels that they need guidance to see her. We usually pass the information that we learn along to other co-workers so that if a particular situation arises again, we will know exactly how to handle this.  This method really does come in handy because you find that as the years pass that you have fewer and fewer questions about your job because the question has already been answered previously and documented.  Personally, I use sticky notes and other forms of reminders to have needed information handy and ready to use when I need it.  I really don't like going to the supervisor for help because it makes me look incompetent.  I like when I can find the solution to a problem on my own without asking for help.  I also like when others that are equal to me come to me for assistance.  I feel that this will help my chances for promotion sometime down the road.  In my opinion, the more others come to you and the less that you go to your supervisor for help, the better it is for you.  The supervisor will remember that you are the one who can work independently and give you a promotion before anyone else.  This is why my relationship with my supervisor is so professional.  I make sure that I only bother her if I really need to.  I never just crack jokes or bother her for no reason.

Q4: person with short-term or long-term responsibility — in the latter sense, usually a generic term; also, one given responsibility over an estate someone in authority or control, as a manager or supervisor or a politician who does not have official status as leader of a political entity but has the actual power.
Q5: Supervisor, when the meaning sought is similar to foreman, foreperson, boss, overseer, cell coach, facilitator, monitor, or area coordinator, is the job title of a low level management position that is primarily based on authority over a worker or charge of a workplace.[1] A Supervisor can also be one of the most senior in the staff at the place of work, such as a Professor who oversees a PhD dissertation. Supervision, on the other hand, can be performed by people without this formal title, for example by parents. The term Supervisor itself can be used to refer to any personnel who have this task as part of their job description.

Q5:
Everyone on my team is unique. They have different skills, different levels of understanding, and different responsibilities and objectives.

Therefore, training and development shouldn't follow a "one size fits all" approach if you want it to be effective. Instead, you need to take the time to understand the training that each individual needs, so that you can provide the right training for the right people. As well as improving performance, this saves time, resources, and money. We have meeting every week.

Q4: He may emerge in a group by virtue of his personality characteristics and qualities or by virtue of common consent by group members. In the latter case, the leader derives his power from the group members. He continues in the leadership position at the pleasure of group members collectively. Leadership position exists in most group settings irrespective of the size of the group.Leadership is an influential process. The leader is in a position to shape, regulate, control and change the attitudes, behaviour and performance of his group members. The latter are supposed to comply with the former’s desires and directives and partially suspend their own judgment and discretion. There exists a particular relationship between the leader and his group members which is characterised by interpersonal and social interaction.
Q5: Supervision is the practice where a counsellor can talk to a professional who is trained to identify any psychological or behavioural changes in the counsellor that could be due to an inability to cope with issues presented by clients. A supervisor is also responsible for challenging practices and procedures, developing improved or different techniques, and informing clients of alternative theories and/or new practices, as well as industry changes. Different ways of evaluating the supervisory process can be important both for the supervisor and the supervisee. Establishing a contract for the supervisory relationship makes evaluation easier.

There are corporate edicts that he and I both disagree with at times and his job is to make sure things are done even though he might agree with me that such demands are at times nearly impossible.

Q4: My manager doesn't provide me with a large amount of coaching and development. However, that is fine with me because I don't want somebody annoying me anyway. He doesn't appear to choose favorites, and we all seem to be on the same level.
Q5: My supervisor provides the practical material support to complete my work objectives. My supervisor politely listens to my concerns and provides advice, although I am realistic and understand that there's not always anything he can do to change things for me. He listens, expresses empathy, and does what he can ay his level to address my concerns and implement my suggestions. My leader provides me with adequate mentioning and coaching without being overbearing and pushy.While its nice to have coaching and mentorship, I believe that you can have too much of a good thing.

Q4: My leader is a former mid-level military officer.  He has not made a noticeable transition from his military days to his new role in managing civilians.  He rules with a slightly weakened iron fist.  He expects full attention and allegiance, doesn't accept the opinions or suggestions of subordinates, is not friendly, can be rude and unforgiving, but runs a productive division within the company. He treats all of his subordinates equally and I suspect that most of my co-workers would share my opinions fairly closely.  There is little if any positive feedback.  The reward in doing the job is to be found in knowing that one's responsibilities to the company and to the customers are being fulfilled at a high level.
Q5: My leader gives little attention to my problems and needs.  He is focused entirely on the company's needs.  I would never ask him for a favor that had potential impact on my productivity.  If I faced a situation with health/safety implications, he would respond according to company policy and procedures.  If I encounter a shortage of a vital tool, supply or other essential need to maintain productivity, he would address that need promptly.  There is a proscribed procedure for doing everything and the leader does not wish to hear subordinates suggestions for changes to procedures.  Coaching and mentoring are not within the skill set of this manager. Giving commands and reprimands are.

Q4: My relationship with my manager is very open. She is future oriented and anticipates changes. She is also open to my feedback as she knows that I can tell what works and what doesn't because I work with the company software on a daily basis. This working relationship has headed off potential project failures because I am able to see the limits of the software in relationship to what my manager is trying to do so that she can implement upgrades and procedure changes. My manager recognizes each of our strengths and weaknesses and works with us on an individual basis. She does not try to get us to compete against each other.
Q5: My supervisor provides thorough training for each employee. This applies at the time of hire as well as during procedural changes. All new hires work with a mentor for at least three months before they are released on their own. Feedback is also provided on an ongoing basis. Continuous improvement and development is encouraged. When a service failure occurs, she will meet with the person to troubleshoot how the failure occured and compare whether the failure occured because of procedural flaws or human error. Then, she will provide feedback on avoidance of the error in the future project or opportunity.

Q4:
My relationship with my "leader" -- the HR representative who is over secretaries -- is rather good.  I'm viewed in sort of two ways by HR:  (1) a very valuable asset who is extremely capable and agreeable - in short, someone who is willing to help whenever needed and who can do almost any task given, whether secretarial, IT, or web design; and (2) someone who they don't really like because I'm very smart and they have the notion that I am a bit superior, which I really try to not convey.  They are always very, very polite and sometimes friendly.  One slight way in which they could show respect more is that when asking a large favor -- to cover someone extra for, say, 3 months, they could be courteous enough to walk down the hall (100 feet) and give the assignment in person.  Obviously, phone is fine for small requests.  

My relationship as opposed to co-workers?  I can't say.  I think they are generally fair and polite to everyone.  Perhaps they have personality favorites -- I do not know.

We get training, but only as needed to do our work.
Q5: My HR rep knows that having a rapport with my attorneys is very important to me.  I think they try to give me good attorneys to work with, but often the attorneys request me, and I get who I get.  They have  often told me that I have been requested, but they have turned the attorney down, as "my plate is full," and I appreciate that, so that allows me to do my work, which is at an advanced level, without getting nickle and dimed death with nuisance requests (that said, I work for 6 partners in the firm, so I am busy).  I don't really get coaching or mentoring from HR, but they run programs on work/life balance and that sort of thing.  When I have problems, I'll go to them - I think this has happened once - and they were helpful.  They listen respectfully and either explain why they cannot make a change or, if not impossible, look into it, which they do promptly.

Q5: Your supervisor is a great resource for you to learn about the history of your company, how to improve your job performance and how to increase your chances for promotion. Q4: I have a great leader, and also a great supervisor.  My leader offered me the job without me even looking for it, and has steadily increased my responsibilities during my time there.  The thing that I appreciate the most is that he sees my potential better than I do; he regularly gives me projects and tasks that I think are too difficult for me, but I manage to do them, and that makes me proud and happy.  He believes in me more than I do.  He often compliments me when I am alone, and also in meetings.  My co-workers have good relationships with him as well, but some of them are afraid of him, and do not speak up as much as I do.  For example, if he gives us a project and it is taking longer than we thought, he is confident that I will be the one to approach him before we get in a bind and will notify him that the scope was too big for the time allotted.
Q5: Like I said above, he is confident that I will approach him if the team is falling behind.  He never questions me and faults us for that, but instead will understand that I would not have come to him if we had not worked our very hardest.  If I need to take some hours off in the day, he never questions it, but assumes that I will make it up later.  He treats me like an adult, and knows that I do my best job possible for him.  Because he has been in the industry for so long, and I haven't, any questions that I have are treated with respect.  He never minds taking the time to teach me.

Q4: My leader provides coaching and development informally, usually by providing suggestions of different ways to handle work and connect with people across the company. He shows respect by listening closely and looking at the details of work product. He has acted as an advocate within the organization, finding opportunities for projects that will strengthen my skills. He also perfectly understands the problems within the company culture and is willing to acknowledge them; giving a realistic picture of how initiatives will unfold. Elements of these traits are common in the company culture, but his transparent style takes these things to a different level.
Q5: He provides a lot of support in the way of making introductions to people across the company to help accomplish objectives. He responds to problems by always being available despite the impossible schedule of an executive. He always makes time to listen, provide feedback, and help if possible. He also values feedback and suggestions and asks for them frequently.

Q4: I have a great relationship with my boss. She's possibly the best supervisor I've ever had - very collegial, very respectful, and appreciative of our value and skills. She is not big on demonstrations of authority or hierarchy, instead she really works as a team member with her team. She does provide direction and a sense of mission, but she really works with us, and never acts in an authoritarian way. About being respectful: she always listens to what we have to say, clearly values our input and lets us take ownership of our projects. And she never acts like she matters more than us in the great scheme of things. As far as I can see, she acts the same way with all her subordinates - I don't feel like I have a "special" relationship with her, she simply is that way with everybody. When it comes to coaching and development though, there is not much of that going on, probably because of time constraints.
Q5: She is quite supportive of our work and understands the challenges we face: we work for a nonprofit organization which doesn't have enough funding to realize all its goals, and the org is basically always trying to do more than is humanly possible with the resources we have.And my boss understands that and sees that, and makes sure to work out solutions with us so that the work gets done without anyone losing their mind or their sleep over it. She is very hands-on in the sense that we discuss things a lot with her and we're all very solution-oriented. When it comes to coaching and mentoring, as I mentioned before, there is not a lot of that happening, although working with her is very informative and inspiring.

Q4: My manager more or less treats me like an equal. She has been a great mentor and helped me to grow my skills a great deal since I have worked for the company. I sometimes think she struggles with delegating and with finishing tasks because she takes on the bulk of the workload, so I try to help her out whenever I can, and I know she appreciates it. When I am feeling overwhelmed, she steps up and takes something off my plate for me. We are also friends outside of work. Overall, I think she is a great leader.
Q5: My manager has been at this company off and on for almost 10 years, so she is familiar with the other employees and understands when I have difficulty with them. When I come across a snag, she is more than happy to help in whatever way she can, either by walking me through it, or explaining to me how she would do it. Our work is artistic in nature, so for the most part she can't do the work for me, if something is too difficult, she helps simplify it so I can complete it. She has provided me with countless free resources that make my job so much easier, and that I never would have been able to find on my own.

Q4: We have weekly staff meetings that are lead by my manager. She uses that time to give the over-all big picture, but also will speak with us individually about tasks and goals. She's also willing to give one-on-one time to focus on my future goals within the organization. I believe the best way my manager shows her respect is to be hands-off. She's not constantly hovering over us to check our work or see what we are doing. I connect more with my manager on a professional level whereas I have coworkers who connect with her additionally on a personal level.
Q5: My manager is very open to my work needs. Whether it's getting the supplies that I need to do my job or clear a path through organizational red tape. She's been around a long time and knows what her employees need to get the job done. She has an open-door policy for any concerns one might have. Thankfully, I have not had to do this very much, but I know that coworkers often go to her to resolve issues. She's extremely helpful when it comes to career coaching. In fact, she's great at recognizing strengths and coming to you with those. She's specifically come to me to ask about career aspirations and to talk about my strengths.

Q4: I mostly have negative opinion with my partner. I sometimes get upset with him. in case of any problems , I have tom face him terribly. I have worst experience compared to my other workers relationship. So my relationship is not that much secure. Passive aggressiveness is a strategy used when a person basically isn’t able to confront issues directly so instead will use indirect means of criticizing you. It could be in the form of comments or actions that make you question yourself or cause you to make mistakes.
Q5: Our leader makes a great support for his workers. But I am the one who has somewhat bad relationship with him. Some managers can demonstrate qualities of manipulative behavior. This is particularly common where there is large power difference with regards to education or authority. This type of boss has so much energy and wants to do everything and wanted it done yesterday. They commit constantly to more projects without checking with the people who actually do the work. Their positive energy is infectious and it is great to be so productive.

Q4: My relationship with my leader is a give and take and is better than most of my fellow co workers. My leader gives me more space and relies on my skills and commitment to take care of my responsibilities without having to be a helicopter leader. My leader has not shown me much coaching beyond my initial training period. However, there are some times when the leader goes out of the way to demonstrate a new selling or promoting technique to me as well as other employees. But for the most part my leader has a hands off approach as looking no as the leader is kept in the loop financially.
Q5: I feel that my leader does understand  and supports most of my needs as an employee. The leader has worked all aspects of the business so knows a great deal of the ends and outs so to speak. My leader does listen to my concerns and provide advise but it is always best to ask for advise at the appropriate time and place. My leader responds to my needs through encouragement and action, for instance if I have a personal obligation my leader will come in and fulfill my role in the company, whether it be a couple of hours or a couple of days.

Q4: My leader is typically there for me and willing to help develop me professionally by providing on site training and development activities throughout the year. She shows that she respects me by understanding if projects do not go correctly as planned and is willing to work with me to figure out better solutions to problems. She allows me to do things my way and lets me work independently without always feeling the need to be over my shoulder. My relationship with my leader is about the same as my coworkers relationship with the leader. There is not much variation in one individual having a much better relationship than another.
Q5: My supervisor is always there for me if I experience any problems and is willing to work with me to solve complications. She brainstorms with me and provides visual support do aid my problem. My supervisor is always available for chatting and makes sure her employees know what their task is and how to solve it. My supervisor doesn't typically provide coaching and mentoring herself, but my workplace does. They offer classes on professional development and we usually do about one "fun" activity among my department each week which is meant to help coach and develop us further in the company.

Q4: I'm the equivalent of Milton in the movie Office Space. I had my own office at one point, now I'm in a cubicle on the other side of the building next to the filing cabinets in a corner all by myself. Everyone forgets that I even work here because I'm that far away from the rest of my coworkers. I'm not included in the department updates, nor the memos, they have meetings without me, etc. My boss gets along with everyone but he is not as friendly with me.
Q5: He doesn't understand my problems and needs. He says we can come to him about anything but he doesn't provide an environment for that purpose. I'm a private person and if I have an issue at work that I feel needs to be elevated to that level, I don't think it's everyone in the entire building's business. The office politics are brutal here.

Q4: We have a good relationship - my manager is less technical than I am in the field we work in, so a lot of our working relationship is less technically-minded, which is a bit frustrating for me - so the coaching aspect of our relationship is less about the actual work I'm doing and more about managing the soft skills of the position. My manager definitely respects me and frequently tells me and others that my contributions are great for the company. Among other coworkers, everybody respects and enjoys being under the leadership of our manager - they do good work.
Q5: Unforunately, this is where I'm a bit out in the cold - with regards to my objectives, I think my manager doesn't quite understand the direction in which I'm trying to lead my department, so a lot of changes that I request are met with an argument about whether or not they make money. While this isn't overly frustrating, it would be nice to have a bit of guidance toward my goals instead of resistance in the steps toward the same goals. I don't receive any formal coaching or mentoring, per se, but we often will discuss aspects of my job and problems with it.

Q4:
My leader routinely coaches me on the softer skills that are required for advancement. He has much faith in my technical skills and abilities to do the job, but he works frequently with me on building out the larger skills required to have long-term success in business. 

He treats me with a friendly demeanor, although not afraid to correct incorrect work or actions firmly. It is honestly a wonderful relationship and I feel he treats my colleagues similarly. 

As a whole, I can say that he has my interests at heart, while also working to advance the organization and I cannot ask much more than that.
Q5:
As previously stated, one of the big things that my leader works with me on is soft people skills. I am still young and working to develop myself in my industry, he is providing guidance that comes with age and previous success. 

There are times with certain problems I feel there is a bit of a disconnect, but leadership is not always about giving you a nice response or what you want to hear, but rather what you need to hear. Overall, I feel I have learned a lot from my leader, skills that I did not necessarily get training for at some of my previous jobs.

Q4:
When I joined the company I was new to the corporate culture. I was even naive about my dressing sense. My supervisor too time to explain me on how to present myself. I was so straight forward and too honest to be compatible with colleagues. He asked me to stop teaching others about morality. He wanted me succeed in life and in my job rather than fighting and teaching others. He asked me to be a role model to others.

After few years, whenever there arises a crisis, he tell everyone to learn from me. 

Though he does the same for others too, only few people learnt from him. I am proud to say I am one among them.
Q5:
My supervisor provide me every opportunity to learn from the organization. My supervisor arranged for few sessions where I can learn a new technology which can be applied in my job as well as useful for my future anywhere.

My supervisor also advised me to take up a post graduation course to improve my qualification. He arranged leaves for my examination. When the higher management was suspicious about my performance because of internal politics, he convinced the management and my talent and performance.

Whenever I have a problem, he either suggest me some good idea or he give me some time to probe on the issue and give a solution. I respect him a lot.

Q4: My leader and I have a good working relationship. We have semi-formal join-ups every quarter (three months) to discuss more work plan as well as my career goals. He also provides me with an assessment of my potential within the company. Outside of these join-ups, we have informal conversations nearly almost every day. We both work near each other so we see each other every day. I enjoy working with someone in person vice remotely. My leader provides very similar feedback and behavior to my other co-workers. Overall he is a good leader that understands his people and enjoys working with others.
Q5: My leader will take the time to listen to any problems that come up with my work assignments. This can occur during our scheduled join-ups and/or meetings, but it can also occur when something immediate is needed. My leader is flexible in meeting the needs of my problems and issues at work. My supervisor provides me coaching and feedback as well. After I present to senior management, we always have a debrief to ask how things went and whether there was anything that needed to be changed. I enjoy this type of feedback because it helps me know and grow in my work environment.

Q4: My leader does not provide much coaching or development.  We have mostly the same work tasks and demands.  He just so happens to have been with the organization longer than I have, so he has seniority over me.  We do mostly the same.  There is no need for him to coach me much, and I'm expected to coach myself, and learn any aspects of the work myself.  He certainly respects me, but he doesn't really show it.  We have a pretty mutual empathetic relationship for each other.  We work alongside of each other to complete the same objectives, and we cooperate and try to stay out of each other's way.
Q5: My leader has a complete understanding of my desires and needs.  We do the same work as each other, so we have a complete understanding of what is needed to accomplish our tasks.  If there is any sort of help that is needed, we will both be able to help each other without being asked, because it's mostly obvious when help is needed.  If there are any concerns, we have no problem letting each other know.  If there is a certain project that needs to be done, we will communicate with each other if the task needs input from both of us.

Q4: My working relationship with my supervisor is nearly perfect. If I make any mistakes, which I rarely do, I can expect fair and concise coaching on the subject. My leader shows that he respects me on a daily basis by asking for my ideas and input on work related manners. I believe that my coworkers also have a very appropriate, warm and friendly relationship with my supervisor. I believe that he is fair and understanding and everyone that appreciates that does benefit from his experience and interactions. If people have a good work ethic they have no trouble getting along with him.
Q5: My supervisor is very good at understanding and determining our problems and needs. This is probably attributed to the act that before becoming my supervisor he held the position of patient service specialist; which is what I am currently in ranking. My supervisor has an open door policy and expects us to approach him with and problem big or small. My supervisor makes my concerns a top priority and always follows up with me on the results of any complaints I have lodged. Whether those complaints concern the business protocols and practices or if it just concerns another organization employee.

Q4: Last year my leader at work was also the one who formally evaluated me so I got to know her pretty well. For the evaluation we had to spend hours together talking about my performance on a really long rubric they must use. I have received a lot of positive feedback, but also had areas identified that I needed help and future training on. My leader shows that she respects me by listening to what I have to say and praising the good things I'm already doing. I believe my coworkers have had the same experiences with this person because she is equitable to all workers.
Q5: I receive direct assistance on whatever I need. If I simply need a strategy, she is able to suggest a strategy because she has been in my position before and has personal experience. Overall, I feel understood.

Q4: I would say that my personal working relationship with my supervisor is better than that with a lot of my other coworkers. He knows that of all the other people here he can count on me to not screw him over in terms of simple things like meeting deadlines or not being late without good cause. We have a good relationship that also includes a fair amount of humor. I would say that we genuinely like each other, which makes it more fun and easy to work here even or especially during the busiest seasonal times. I think that I would spend effort to maintain this status.
Q5: I think that he does a really good job of making sure that anyone who feels like they are falling behind has all of the support they need in order to make it on a day to day basis. Any time I am thinking of going back for training or anything like that, he always has a positive response that is based on reality. It's good to work with someone who is so level headed and easy to get along with. It makes the daily grind easier to deal with when you have some level of support around you each day.

Q4: I have a good relationship with my supervisor.  She does not really need to coach or develop my technical skills but she does coach me on how to handle policies and regulations set by the company.  I really believe that she values my work and respects my effort and knowledge of the industry.  She seems to have a good relationship with other employees but she does seem to rely on me more than she does on others.  She appreciates the fact that I need little guidance and I am always helping others.  When she is not there she usually puts me in charge.
Q5: My supervisor is great at communicating with me.  She knows that sometimes I just need to vent and is always willing to listen when I have an issue. She understands that all I need is to be heard sometimes, even though she may not be able to fix that particular situation. Whenever I am given a large workload she will always offer help.  She is willing to compromise and is fair. She often speaks highly of me to other coworkers and also to her supervisors. From my experience she always leads by example and that is something that many supervisors don't do.

Q4: Almost for any work my leader believe me to a extent that he simply asks me to carry out the job. Whenever he has doubt in his work without any hesitation or ego he asks me to clarify it. We have a mutual understanding that we both work for the best and we respect each other. The co-workers also have a cordial relationship with me and with the leader. We work as a team to achieve the good ideals of the department. Moreover everyone in the team is more caring, flexible and friendly to work with. Great team work together!!
Q5: My leader makes sure that the co-worker's are provided with balanced working hours. He is caring enough to assign easy to carry out projects. The relationship is kept strong as we have the freedom to work in flexible working conditions. The supervisor is kind enough to listen to our concerns and advice us accordingly. Whenever we are faced with any problem our supervisor gives necessary coaching and mentoring to help us resolve them immediately. Last week the management was asking us to provide a report within 2 hours which was very difficult to prepare. The supervisor immediately volunteered to talk to the management and helped in getting some more time to submit the report.

Q4: I have a difficult working relationship with my leader. It is very inconsistent and I never know how she will react to a particular situation on any given day. Somedays it may be a positive reaction but sometimes there is a negative reaction to the same situation. I receive an equal amount of coaching and development as most other staff although there are a few who are shown more respect in situations. I have learned that if I approach at the right time and in the right way, I will have better, more positive reactions. It's also better to ask for development as it's more likely to happen if it's asked for than if you wait for it to be offered.
Q5: I would say my supervisor's door is always open to discuss problems, but it has to be presented at the right time. My supervisor is there to listen but doesn't generally offer solutions or clear advice. It's generally left up to the employee to figure out. In some ways there is freedom to solve problems or complete tasks in the way you think best, but there isn't always guidance when needed on how to accomplish it. And sometimes if there is guidance, it isn't always in touch with what is feasible. A general example would be when resources to complete a task aren't available. The solution given would be to go buy what is needed. However, funding isn't actually available for the purchase.

Q4: My working relationship with my supervisor is mediocre at best. He is not what I would call a "leader". He is very relaxed and laid back, which is fine, but not all the time. He is quite a bit younger than me and he just does not see the big picture. He does not reprimand and document other employees who should have been terminated years ago. I have a much better relationship with my colleagues and subordinates. I believe my supervisor needs more training and should take appropriate classes on how to be an effective and efficient leader for our team.
Q5: My supervisor does a better job with this as I had some personal issues arise approximately 3 months into my job. He was understanding and allowed me to make up work as needed. Regarding taking advice and recommendations from me, he does not do that. I have 13 years on him and have been in the workforce since I was 11 years of age. If someone comes to me with an idea I look at it from every angle to see if it is possible to institute. If it is not, I let them know I appreciate their effort but at this time that recommendation is not feasible.

Q4: My working relationship with my leader is highly respectful.  He is very intelligent, communicates well, and considers my input.  He is respectful to everyone and encourages good collaboration among all workers.  He is good about spelling out specific expectations, providing needed information to complete tasks and projects and providing enough space and independence and trust of others to get the job done.  He is professional and expects professionalism of everyone.  He is a great role model, he illustrates an excellent eye for details, reliability and accountability, and is very well-organized.  He has been in his profession for more than 30 years and has a strong history with the organization.  He is an excellent resource.
Q5: I work in the public sector at a state university.  As such, my supervisor considers that my needs are being met by the job itself.  Unfortunately the department does not offer job growth, as a Program Coordinator there isn't another position to grow into.  I have a variety of interesting tasks and am counted on to help in many ways, but one of my needs (job growth, pay raise, etc.) is not being met.  This is true of many workers at the University, and especially true for my particular department.  My leader is limited by the definition of my job title.

Q4: My leader works very closely with me. Because I am on the tail end of being new, he provides a lot of guidance and feedback on the work that I do. He is always respectful of how he presents that feedback and always takes into account how much effort I put into the product that he is reviewing. He is efficient at what he does, does not drag his feet on any request, and is always willing to take some time to help out. He does this for all coworkers who ask for it--because some coworkers have been here for quite a bit of time, they don't need as much guidance as I do, but will seek it out from him. He is always happy to help.
Q5: My leader understands my problems and needs generally pretty well. I get the sense that he used to have the portfolio that I currently work on, because he is very familiar with it, so he is able to understand my explanations of the work very easily, and is also able to ask pointed, insightful questions that might reveal errors or inconsistencies in what I have done (or, sometimes, reaffirm that my approach was the correct approach). This kind of questioning is one of the many ways he provides coaching and mentoring. He listens very well, and seems to take into consideration my concerns, but seems, occasionally, too willing to dismiss them outright. I say that only because he's gone back and said, "well, actually that was a good idea" a couple of times--which, at the very least, shows that he is considerate and willing to admit mistakes, which is great, so I don't begrudge him at all for immediately dismissing some ideas.

Q4: What I like about my manager, Paula, is that whenever she tells us that she needs some of us to volunteer for an assignment, she also is the first one to volunteer.  I really respect her for that.  A lot of managers feel that they are above it all and only want the workers to do the extra work.  Not Paula, she is always at the head of the line and I find that inspiring.  She is the kind of supervisor that I would want to be.  I consider myself lucky to have her as my boss.
Q5: Paula is a great coach and mentor.  She really listens to me and we can talk one on one, as equals.  If I have a problem or don't understand something, she will help me in any way I need help.  She gives me advice, career-wise, and seems really interested in my progress at work.  She does the same for everyone else in the department, too.  She is also very good at defending us when someone at the top has a question or complaint.  She is always there for us.  She has our backs.

Q4: My relationship with my boss is pretty good in comparison with my coworkers. We seem to have a pretty friendly relationship. However, in general with all of us, he does not provide us with enough direction and expects us to know where to head next. There are some occasions where he makes suggestions, but a lot of the time he just waits for you to present what you have done and offers his critiques and comments for things to improve. Basically he wants us to develop to a point where we know what he wants without being told in advance.
Q5: My boss definitely will listen to concerns and provide advice if asked directly. He won't turn you away or say no most of the time when you ask unless it is something he views as 'easy' or 'obvious'. Not much help is provided in terms of actual mentoring to become better at our jobs, because he feels like it is our responsibility to push ourselves to learn and become independent. However, he will make himself available to act as a sounding board to voice concerns and needs, especially if they are personal. I was actually reprimanded by him for not notifying him of something that was going on in my personal life so that he could make sure to lower his expectations and give me time to handle things.

Q4: My manager does not provide a whole lot of coaching or development opportunities, but rather relies on us to further ourselves professionally. This is the same for all employees except for maybe a few who are new to the company. I generally feel respected as there is general interest in my personal life, politeness in our work environment, and there is a lot of trust placed on me such as being left alone in the store with valuable merchandise for days at a time. Not all employees have a chummy relationship with the boss, and some even go out of their way to avoid interacting with management.
Q5: My leader does not provide a whole lot of feedback in any respect of my job, which I find extremely frustrating sometimes. I typically have to ask questions and advice when I feel uncomfortable with a job or aspect of a particular product, customer, or sale experience. My boss could be more proactive and provide more training so I feel more prepared before encountering these types of situations, but alas that's not how it goes. My boss is fairly good at giving advice when asked to give it, but sometimes I feel very much left on my own to figure it out.

Q4: My leader has trained me from my initial hiring, and provides updates on my progress and performance regularly. He meets with me at least twice a month and visits with me daily. He also responds to my emails and questions in a timely manner, and helps me with any problems I have. He gets people to help when my computer isn't working and I can't do aspects of my job, and isn't frustrated with me when this happens but understands it's out of my control. Other coworkers have similar relationships with him. Our whole team likes our manager because he is a good leader.
Q5: My supervisor listens to my problems and needs pretty well. He has listened to me give me goals and then provides objectives for me to accomplish them. He tells me what I need to work on. He also coaches me when other coworkers can't. He QCs my work and gives me feedback. In person and email correspondence, he will provide relevant and useful feedback, and doesn't forget our conversations, but references them. He also tells senior coworkers how they can help me, and also gets their feedback on my performance too. He listens to my concerns and attempts to address them.

Q4: My leader is awesome.  He always listens to my issues and advises me.  I respect him because he has worked here longer than I have and has been involved in so many different areas of the company.  He seems to think things through with a clear head and not get too angry.  I can tell him anything and I know he will have my back.  He keeps things light with our team and he is very flexible.  I think he gives me a little more respect than the others on the team b/c I am most senior.
Q5: My supervisor listens to the problems and tries to think of a logical and practical solution.  If I am having trouble with a certain sales guy, he will try to address this.  If I am having problem with an account, he will help me pool my resources and will keep following up until I am satisfied with the resolution. Q4: My manager and I have a fairly good working relationship. His approach is rather hands off. This is ok most of the time but there are times when specific directions, guidance, and feedback would be helpful and appreciated. Q4: I think the best thing my leader does is not interfere. I technically have two leaders, which are the founders of the Pit Bull rescue where I work some days and volunteer the others (because it's not in the budget to pay me full time). I've been with this rescue for 4 years. I was involved in dog rescue (volunteering and fostering) for 8 years prior. The founders of the rescue know my history. We may not always see eye-to-eye on certain things, but they give me my freedom when it comes to working with the dogs. They do still require certain routines, but other than that, they trust my judgement. They are not the same with the board members or other volunteers. The three of us are the only people that handle certain dogs. They also know if there is a rescue call or if I'm out helping look for a lost animal, transporting, or whatever that I am going to handle myself in a way that positively reflects the rescue. We have become very good friends through the years. Thank you is never needed. They know if they need me they don't even have to ask. They treat me the same way. If I have an emergency tomorrow or just need help with something, I know they'll be there. We have gone through many periods where we didn't speak for more than a week because of a difference of opinion, but it doesn't change our commitment to the animals, and therefore, we eventually move past it.
